cluster_relations.rel_desc: Waving hello is given as an example of a gesture.
A thumbs up is presented as an example of a gesture.
A furrowed brow is presented as a kind of facial expression.
remarks: Partly supported by entity description; treated as facial expression instance.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links a specific example or instance to the more general class or category it belongs to.
args.justification: In all three relations, the subject is a concrete example (waving hello, thumbs up, furrowed brow) and the object is a broader category (gestures, facial expressions). This is best modeled as an instance-to-class relation rather than a generic 'type_of' label.
args.remark: Normalized all example-of/category relations in this chunk to the canonical predicate 'is_instance_of'.

args.justification: These relations express taxonomic categorization, connecting individual nonverbal behaviors to their broader gesture/facial-expression categories, fitting a classification/taxonomy relation class.
args.remark: Used a generic but specific-enough class name to cover instance-to-category and similar taxonomy edges.

args.justification: Instance-of and taxonomic categorization relations are best grouped under a broad identity/equivalence dimension, since they define what kind of thing the subject is relative to a general category.
